spanishExample: ¡Qué suerte! ¡Lo veo ahora!
englishTranslation: How lucky! I see it now!
vocabIncluded: veo: see, I see (Ver, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¡Quiero verte! No te he visto desde hace años.
englishTranslation: I want to see you! I haven’t seen you since years ago.
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Ahora lo ves? Él dijo que lo vio.
englishTranslation: Do you see it now? He said he saw it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ves: see, you see (Ver, present, 2nd person)
vio: saw, he/she/it saw (Ver, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¿Viste eso? Se suponía que íbamos a estar ahí.
englishTranslation: Did you see that? Supposedly we were going to be there.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
suponerse: any use of Suponer with a reflexive, plus "que", pronoun, changing the meaning to "supposedly"
suponía: supposed, he/she/it supposed (Suponer, imperfect, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
viste: saw, you saw (Ver, preterite, 2nd person)
íbamos: "were going", "we were going" (Ir, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: A ver qué es exactamente lo que viste.
englishTranslation: Let’s see what is exactly what you saw.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"qué" in an implied question, not an actual question
viste: saw, you saw (Ver, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: A ver si pusieron las cosas en el lugar.
englishTranslation: Let’s see if they put the things in the place.
vocabIncluded: pusieron: put, they put (Poner, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: A ver si realmente tiene miedo.
englishTranslation: Let’s see if he really is afraid.

spanishExample: Ahora lo vemos, pero ella lo vio antes.
englishTranslation: We see it now, but she saw it before.
vocabIncluded: vemos: see, we see (Ver, present, 1st person plural)
vio: saw, he/she/it saw (Ver, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Ahora veo lo que ves.
englishTranslation: Now I see what you see.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
veo: see, I see (Ver, present, 1st person)
ves: see, you see (Ver, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Ellos lo ven así, pero nosotros no lo vemos así.
englishTranslation: They see it that way, but we don’t see it that way.
vocabIncluded: así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"
vemos: see, we see (Ver, present, 1st person plural)
ven: see, they see (Ver, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Estamos viendo lo que queremos que usted vea.
englishTranslation: We’re seeing what we want you(formal) to see.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment
vea: see, he/she/it see (Ver, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Están viendo ahora lo que yo había visto.
englishTranslation: They are seeing now what I had seen.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
había: "had", "I had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: Lo ve, pero no quiere que tú lo veas.
englishTranslation: He sees it, but he doesn’t want you to see it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ve: sees, he/she/it sees (Ver, present, 3rd person)
veas: see, you see (Ver, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Lo ven, pero quiero que lo pongan ahí.
englishTranslation: They see it, but I want them to put it there.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
pongan: put, they put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)
ven: see, they see (Ver, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Lo vieron y ahora quieren que él lo vea.
englishTranslation: They saw it and now they want him to see it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
vea: see, he/she/it see (Ver, subjunctive, 3rd person)
vieron: saw, they saw (Ver, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Mi equipo va a estar ahí y yo lo voy a ver.
englishTranslation: My team is going to be there and I’m going to see it.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: No lo vi, pero quería verlo.
englishTranslation: I didn’t see it, but I wanted to see it.
vocabIncluded: vi: saw, I saw (Ver, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: No lo voy a ver porque ellos lo ven.
englishTranslation: I’m not going to see it because they see it.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
ven: see, they see (Ver, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Quieres que veamos cuando pongas esas cosas ahí.
englishTranslation: You want us to see when you put those things there.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
pongas: put, you put(Poner, subjunctive, 2nd person plural)
veamos: see, we see (Ver, subjunctive, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Quiero que veamos lo que él ve mañana.
englishTranslation: I want us to see what he sees tomorrow.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ve: sees, he/she/it sees (Ver, present, 3rd person)
veamos: see, we see (Ver, subjunctive, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Quizás vean a la familia hoy.
englishTranslation: Maybe they’ll see the family today.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person
vean: see, they see (Ver, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Supongo que siquiera tiene que verlo.
englishTranslation: I guess she at least has to see him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supongo: suppose, I suppose (Suponer, present, 1st person)
tener que ver: have to do (with) (idiom)

spanishExample: Supuse que lo habías visto.
englishTranslation: I supposed that you had seen it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
habías: "had", "you had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 2nd person)
supuse: supposed, I supposed (Suponer, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Tampoco vimos a esa gente.
englishTranslation: We didn’t see those people either.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person
vimos: saw, we saw (Ver, preterite, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Te tengo cariño y por eso quiero verte.
englishTranslation: I’m fond of you and that’s why I want to see you.
vocabIncluded: te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
tenerle cariño a alguien: to be fond of someone (idiom)

spanishExample: Ve que es demasiado para él.
englishTranslation: He sees that it’s too much for him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ve: sees, he/she/it sees (Ver, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Vi a mis amigos en su casa.
englishTranslation: I saw my friends at their house.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person
vi: saw, I saw (Ver, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Voy a ver a mi familia porque ellos quieren que los vea.
englishTranslation: I’m going to see my family because they want me to see them.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
"the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
vea: see, I see (Ver, subjunctive, 1st person)
